Content: 2 *p38419a0216* answer all questions. 1 a student wishes to find the density of a metre rule. the width of the rule is about 28 mm and the thickness is about 6 mm. (a) in the table below write the names of the instruments you would use to make each of  these measurements. measurement instrument width thickness     give a reason for your choices. (2)   (b) the student records measurements from several positions along the rule. width/mm 28.2,  29.3,  28.9,  29.0,  29.1 thickness/mm 6.04,  5.94,  5.97,  6.01,  5.99 mass/g 106.4     use these measurements to calculate a value for the density of the rule. (3)       density =  pmt

3 *p38419a0316* turn over (c) estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value for the density.  assume the  uncertainty in the mass is negligible. (3)         percentage uncertainty for the density =  (total for question 1 = 8 marks) pmt

4 *p38419a0416* 2 a student writes a plan to obtain a value for the distance travelled in air by alpha  particles. he plans to use an alpha particle source, a geiger-m ller tube with a thin window and a  counter. his diagram is shown below. he writes the following plan place the geiger mu..ller tube in front of the source. measure the distance, d, from the source to the tube. measure the count. change d and take more readings. geiger-mu..ller tube o to counter source holder pmt

5 *p38419a0516* turn over his teacher says that the plan needs more detail. add more detail to improve this plan, include one safety precaution he should take. you may add to the diagram if you wish. (6)                   (total for question 2 = 6 marks) pmt

6 *p38419a0616* 3 the diagram below shows a flask containing air.  a pressure gauge is screwed into the  top of the flask. you are to plan an experiment to see how the pressure of the air in the flask varies with  temperature. (a) (i) add to the diagram to show how you would vary the temperature of the air in  the flask. (2)     (ii) describe how you would change the temperature over the range 0  c to 100  c. (1)    pressure gauge metal flask pmt

7 *p38419a0716* turn over     (iii) suggest how you would determine the temperature of the air in the flask. (1)        (iv) describe what you would do to make your readings as accurate as possible. (2)      (b) use the axes below to show how you would expect the pressure of the air in the flask  to vary with temperature. (3) (total for question 3 = 9 marks) pressure temperature pmt

8 *p38419a0816* 4 a designer needs a circuit that will cause a delay in switching off the interior light in a  car after the door is shut. she uses a circuit with a resistor and a capacitor.  she knows that the time constant t is given by t = rc where r is the resistance in ohms and c is the capacitance in farads. with the switch in position x the capacitor is charged to 12 v.  when the switch is  moved to position y the capacitor discharges through the resistor and the potential  difference (p.d.) across the resistor falls steadily from 12 v. (a) (i) calculate a theoretical value for the time constant for this circuit. (1)   time constant  =      (ii) what is the significance of the time constant for such a discharge? (1)   12 v     n  v 100  f y x high resistance  digital voltmeter pmt

9 *p38419a0916* turn over (b) she decides to check the theoretical value for the time constant t using a stopwatch,  with a precision of 0.01s.     (i) state why the voltmeter needs to have a high resistance. (1)        (ii) state why a stopwatch is suitable for measuring the time in this context. (1)        (iii) state what she should do to make her value for t as reliable as possible. (1)    (c) for a capacitor discharging through a resistor, the potential difference v across the  resistor at time t is given by v = v0 e t/rc     explain why a graph of ln v against t should be a straight line. (2)     question 4 continues on the next page pmt

10 *p38419a01016* (d) the designer uses the circuit to obtain the following data. t/s v/v 0 12.00 5 9.41 10 7.16 15 5.49 20 4.55 25   3.49 30 2.68 35 2.04     plot a graph on the grid opposite to show that these data are consistent with  v = v0 e t/rc.     use the extra column in the table above for your processed data. (4) pmt
